Anonymous Thu 05 Aug 2021 00:14:18 No.40680614 Report
Quoted By: >>40680694
Replying here:

>>40679789
Writers who don't understand mental illness treat it like illnesses that can cured, or injuries that can be rehabilitated. They think ptsd can be cured by smothering the "traumatic event" in "unconditional" love, acceptance, and whatever other well-intentioned ideals they've romanticized in their self-gratifying fever dreams. Those relationships DO NEED those things, but dispel any notion of a cure – it is a lifetime of adapting, constant acceptance, understanding, mutual struggle and desire... all things that categorically fall under unconditional love. Those relationships are rarely successful when they're founded on the complex of a fixed emotional reward.
Anonymous

>Why would characters even bother with someone who has PTSD in a romance story anyway?

>A strong support network can dramatically decrease the impact of something like PTSD, though.
You mean dramatically decrease the impact of visible symptoms? PTSD is not like cold that you get only temporarily. You can't get rid of memories. Some people become lesser people coping by telling themselves what happened wasn't that bad, trying to distract themselves with progress, or that what happened can't define who they are what they can become.

All of these are white lies. You will only ever have one amygdala, and you can damage it, and you will never be able to be normal or healthy again.

>>40680681
Christ, you make it sound like they're enemy NPCs who are universally FUBAR beyond any hope of redemption, as though that's even a prerequisite to begin with. People with ptsd can fall in love, adapt, change, internalize their grief/panic episodes, whatever might be needed to meet their friends, family, and romantic partners somewhere in the middle. Nobody asks for ptsd – like anyone else, if they WANT to be received well, they will endeavor to follow the social template for affable & well-adjusted people as closely as they can. They can, and do, want to be good to, and for, the people they love.

Anonymous Thu 05 Aug 2021 00:55:40 No.40681491 Report
Quoted By: >>40681561 >>40681652 >>40681954 >>40682545
>>40681173
One trope I've always liked, and I feel is criminally underserved, in the whole Sci-Fantasy thing is a Fantasy world undergoing development much like our own. I always looked at these Fantasy worlds and thought it was retarded that they arbitrarily stayed stuck in some weird, gunpowderless version of Late Medieval times. Especially with all the shit Fantasy likes to pull with fallen empires and such having been sophisticated in some way that the current empires aren't, clearly indicating that there's room for improvement. And I always thought it's kind of bullshit how a lot of settings that do go this way do the whole magic and technology clashing thing. And then there's Steampunk, of course, which is this sort of thing for people with poor taste and a poor grasp of engineering.

I've never been that much into Shadowrun, either. Dragonfall was good, Hong Kong good-ish, but the entire setting is just painfully outdated. That's kind of a feature of Cyberpunk as a genre, but Shadowrun also leans way too hard into the insufferable edgy part of Cyberpunk. I'm more into Rifts, but have barely played it. It's just unapologetically weird. And who knows, maybe they make female versions of those dog soldiers?

Anyway, that's kind of the issue, I guess. I just want it plain. Fantasy world, but with realistic technological development, no weird added flavors. I think that's flavor enough. I mean, do people start making flying warships? Do long-lived species like Elves get left behind in hopeless conservatism? Do frost enchantments on gun barrels facilitate higher rates of fire?
Anonymous

Guy who first mentioned checking out the
"Curses" novel here. I'm about halfway through now.
If you can get past some minor things, like a token non-binary side character, there are some cute hmofa scenes.
Some typical stuff you see around here, like the beast resisting the urge to sniff the human male.
Some interesting exploration of what utensils don't work well for snouts (turns out soup is a bad idea).
One particularly fun moment where she falls off of a dock, roars at the bird that chased her off the dock, shakes herself dry like a dog, and then looks up at all the party guests now no longer partying and all staring at her.
I'm still worried it will end with the predictable cured curse ending of course.

>>40681561
We see the Medieval period as a period of stagnation thanks to Renaissance memery, mostly. It's been incredibly persistent, and even when I was young you'd see that edgy atheist meme everywhere, claiming we'd be exploring the galaxy if it wasn't for backwards Christianity ruining Rome's fun. But anyone who opens a history book knows this is absolute horse shit, and the Renaissance flowed naturally from Medieval times in terms of technological progress. Medieval times were times of rapid technological progress compared to all era's before it. Once I realized this, it started looking weirder and weirder to me that stereotypical Fantasy takes this captured in resin approach to the whole thing, where the presence of things they lifted from history without question already suggests a massive technological and scientific base level.

>>40683712
Yes, very easily, but Dead Space is as hard of sci-fi as Halo.
You have to remember that FTL travel should either be difficult (from a technical point) or impossible with Hard Sci-Fi as theoretically there isn't enough energy in the universe to propel a particle faster than the speed of light, which is how Interstellar of all things gets the Hard Sci-Fi label.

You could have the humans or anthros land on each other's planets, i.e human/anthro generation ship lands on another planet, some political bull shit (joint exploration, trade venture , whatever real life potential reason) or you could have it be a political themed story with colonies, asteroid mining rights and stuff being debated and one or more parties need assurance it'll work (political marriage is great for settings with nobility, I intend to do a tribes spinoff following it one day)

  • Post

Anonymous Thu 05 Aug 2021 03:02:26 No.40683833 Report
Quoted By: >>40684011
>>40683712
Dead Space is pretty fucking far from hard sf, in my opinion. Laser guns, space zombies, and arbitrary Gothic design doesn't scream hard sf to me.

But yes, arguably better than some other settings (such as dancing around the issue in modern settings). Genetic modification is something that's well at home in the genre, and you can go a lot of ways with it. Ye ol' engineered servant species, for instance. It's a little trite, but everyone knows what's up. But also consciously induced genetic drift in a population, asking the question of how human they remain. Or people editing their own genome for fun, profit, and social acceptance. Or even some NEET scientist with money to spend and a CRISPR setup and boom, now there's animal people in the world. Because he wanted them to be there, and you can't go back.

The only spanner in the works is that, because of the nature of the genre, you HAVE to explain them.
Anonymous

One of the things that helped me on my latest project in the drafts (sitting at about 105k now) was to chapterize it early in the writing process and make each chapter tighter.
Punch into each chapter with a good first sentence/paragraph hook, end on a similar note, and worry less about what tone I had than executing a three or four step plot structure.
Even the pieces I've tossed off as flashbacks for my notes feel like complete short stories.

I guess what I'm trying to say is I've been through that waffling between purple/beige, and my way out was to focus on letting the characters do their thing.
So when I get back to the <REDACTED> piece I'm working on, I'm hoping each scene fragment is like another stone crushing the reader. By the last few lines, I want and should have people crying like a bride's mother.

Best of luck, Smiling, and keep writing.
Only way the two of us are getting better.

Anonymous Thu 05 Aug 2021 03:51:56 No.40684661 Report
Quoted By:
>>40684008
"Hardness" in sci-fi is a sliding scale indicating how closely a story of that genre adheres to scientific theory and/or how thoroughly authors explain things. I don't think it needs to be perfectly engineered, textbook scientific obeisance, but if it's /hard/, your interstellar travel methods are fleshed out, detailed, and you can explain it all at incredible lengths, even if it's bullshit.
Mechanized Memories takes the fantastical approach (imo), where everything has an explanation that sufficiently suspends disbelief because it's thorough, complex, and - thus - utterly convincing. If you've read it, you know it departs pretty far from the hard stuff.
The Heartless Ranger was written by an engineering student who drew inspiration FROM QtR's MM, but wanted his scientific adherence to follow scientific theory as strictly as possible. To my knowledge, it's the best example of hard sci-fi among most /hmofa/ stories available.
In soft sci-fi, everything just werks, man. Don't gotta think about it, you just get in your space mustang and fly.

Anonymous Thu 05 Aug 2021 12:15:26 No.40690162 Report
Quoted By:
>>40689218
That doesn't necessarily dissuade my interest, but if your goal from the outset is wholesome, why not hone in on a compromise? If your proclivities favor struggle and suffrage, try incorporating those elements into your plot.
Give your characters something to overcome, an opposing force of some sort. Doesn't need to be a tangible antagonist; perhaps they might face cultural or societal backlash, eg A Bronx Tale. Is your budding romance chaffing with an older long-term goal, a self-destructive quest? Gangs of New York it. Are they childhood sweethearts who inherit a bitter conflict they're slowly dragged into, despite their mutual desires?
I'm just spitballin'. But ultimately, no matter the events and beats between your epilogue, you can write a wholesome underdog story or a grimdark urban fantasy, and still end it on a happy, satisfactory note.

Anonymous Thu 05 Aug 2021 13:17:36 No.40690669 Report
Quoted By: >>40691837
>>40690331
I think I grasp the current trend well enough. I have no interest in reading LeGuin because I find her writing style to be grating, and her themes (such I've heard of them) do not interest me. Most modern science fiction and fantasy does not interest me. Long ago I was of the belief that while I enjoyed older writers, their equivalents must exist in the current landscape, and went in search of them. I found none, and many misleading opinions about the quality of their work. Of course, this isn't some hard distinction where all older writers were good (indeed, LeGuin is one of those older writers), but I do find it peculiar that I've found better writing when reading books from the 60's someone literally found abandoned in some basement than I did when purposefully looking for good modern writing.

Of course, if you do know of good modern authors, I would gladly hear of them.
